@SkidanovAlex In this test case, the shape of `inp` is  (128, 200000). The embedding layer will output a tensor with shape (128, 200000, 10) while the FC layer will output a (128, 10) tensor. The output tensor dominates the memory consumption, which explains the doubling behavior.

Also, for the embedding layer, the input are integers before one-hot encoding.
maybe size of the data transferred from gpu to cpu is bigger and bigger.

https://github.com/itayhubara/BinaryNet.
bmp is very store space consuming, why not to convert it to jpg or png.

Because `bmp` format is not compressed. If i want to keep all the pixel info, I can not use `jpeg`.
`png` seems to support loss-compression and lossness-compression, but I'm not sure whether `bin/im2rec` supports png lossness-compression.
@antinucleon As a pooling operation, ROIPooling did not request any temporary space. From roi_pooling.cu:120, we can see ROIPoolForwardKernel failed with out of memory. Any idea why this happened?

why do we need embedding_layer?
what is it for?

int im2rec.cc, it use `cv::Mat img = cv::imdecode(decode_buf, color_mode);` to get image data. this function supports bmp format also.
I think you just have a try to change some code to let im2rec support bmp.
@starimpact E.g word embedding
what is the "_choice"?
OK, I'll give it a try : )

@sxjscience, I trace the shapes in the script provided, and they are consistent with what I originally posted:
1. FC layer will have shape `(10, 200000)`, not `(128, 10)`.
2. Embedding layer has shape `(200000, 10)`, moreover it asserts in the `embedding-imp.h`  that the weight tensor is two dimensional :)

But I agree that my example overall is wrong, since the input shape for the embedding layer should be one-dimensional. When I fix it by changing this line:

`arg_shape, out_shape, aux_shape = f.infer_shape(inp = (128, in_dim))`

with

`arg_shape, out_shape, aux_shape = f.infer_shape(inp = (128,) if test_embeddings else (128, in_dim))`

It stops exploding memory, so I guess it is somehow specific to providing 2d input to the Embedding tensor. I would still consider the original issue posted as worth investigating (it is not obvious why should memory double if the input to the Embedding layer is two dimensional), but since it works properly for the 1d input, which is the intended use case, I guess my original suspicion that Embedding layers do not share weights is incorrect.

@SkidanovAlex Embedding layer supports 2D input. You can print the out_shape and the out_shape of embedding layer should be (128, 200000, 10) while the out_shape of fc layer should be (128, 10). That should be the cause.

@SkidanovAlex  My previous explanation is not so clear. What I mean is that the total memory consumption consists of both the allocation of network arguments (e.g the embedding weight) and the allocation of input/output tensors. For the embedding layer, the shape of the output tensor will be (128, 400000, 10) after concatenation, which is two times larger than the non-concatenation case. Since the output tensor is much larger than the embedding weight whose shape is (200000, 10), it will dominate the memory consumption.

For anyone else coming across this. Setting 
`ADD_CFLAGS = -D_MWAITXINTRIN_H_INCLUDED -D__STRICT_ANSI__`
in make/config.mk solved it for me (based on [this](https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/issues/1066#issue-133111577)).
If you create variables explicitly, you should follow the same naming convention, i.e. xxx_weight for weights and xxx_bias for bias.
@piiswrong I explicitly create variables for sharing weight in RNN, just like the RNN example in MxNet repo.

it is normal.
the data transfer from gpu and cpu is slower as your data is bigger.

`header` must be `kMXAPINDArrayListMagic`.
It has no problem.

Can you propose a list of operator like the #2302, so we can have some idea on what to be done?

I had some experience on FP16 implementation. But those changed are not merged yet(the lstm needs extra input which involves too many changes in example). I'll list the problems I met in fp16 below, so you have a idea of what you might encounter.
- extending operators support to binary. (shadow enhancement is need.)
- kvstore only support preliminary type now. you binary type might have issue in merging different device gradients and different machine gradients. (Binary enhancement is need in ps-lite.)
- initialization of data in binary type(random for binary type?)

Hi @sbodenstein ,   I see it's a design element for RNN in cudnn, and should not be a problem usually. However, the code for mx.model.FeedForward would not work with it, as it assumes all input params to be in the shape of (batch_size,...).

@starimpact this is a help function to sample word randomly.
def _choice(population, weights):
    assert len(population) == len(weights)
    cdf_vals = _cdf(weights)
    x = random.random()
    idx = bisect.bisect(cdf_vals, x)
    return population[idx]
@chenboheng It can be implemented by sharing the weight/bias symbols. The LSTM example may be helpful https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/rnn/lstm.py#L17-L113 .
what is the "_cdf"?

@liuzhi136 That is to sample from $p(x_{t+1} | \hat{x}_{1:t})$. This may be helpful for multi-step prediction. You can refer to the theory of Sequential Monte-Carlo (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Particle_filter).
@sxjscience cannot see the formula.
But I have tried erase disk and re-install OS several times, the errors still exist
@sxjscience It's difficult for me to understand the article in (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Particle_filter).  Formula's meaning is word's prob of x_t+1 given first t words. Is that right?

Everything is async in mxnet, so these timer won't give you actual time cost
You can try nvprof to see how much idle time there is

@liuzhi136 Yes. Assume we want to predict the next k words, i.e, x_{t+1:t+k}. The estimator can be $\arg\max_{x_{t+1:t+k}} p(x_{t+1:t+k}) \mid \hat{x}_{1:t})$.  The problem is how to solve this optimization problem based on our model for one-step prediction, which is given by the RNN. One observation is that for every specific $x_{t+1:t+k}$, we can easily compute its probability. However, it would be impossible for us to enumerate all the combinations and we need to find some approximate solutions. There are two possible ways for that, Beam Search (deterministic) and Sequential Monte-Carlo (probabilistic). For beam search, the idea is to always keep the word trajectories that have the highest likelihood. For sequential monte-carlo, the idea is to give a particle approximation of the distribution and update these particles.

It seems if the network has more complex structures, it becomes not that stable. Here I use the residual structure from "example" folder. I changed number of filters for each group to increase the capcity of the network. and I also remove the alst fc and pooling layer to allow different input shapes. If I bind the network with say data = (1, 3, 1000, 1000), the memory usage is around 1533MB when the input size is fixed. If I bind the network with this maximum input size and reshape it using different smaller sizes, I will get out of memory soon. I have only 4GB gpu memory. The problem seems that the new executor does not really share the memory with the old one. 
I have pasted code here, please have a look. @piiswrong @tqchen 

```
import mxnet as mx


def conv_factory(data, num_filter, kernel, stride, pad, act_type='relu', conv_type=0):
    if conv_type == 0:
        conv = mx.symbol.Convolution(data=data, num_filter=num_filter, kernel=kernel, stride=stride, pad=pad)
        bn = mx.symbol.BatchNorm(data=conv)
        act = mx.symbol.Activation(data=bn, act_type=act_type)
        return act
    elif conv_type == 1:
        conv = mx.symbol.Convolution(data=data, num_filter=num_filter, kernel=kernel, stride=stride, pad=pad)
        bn = mx.symbol.BatchNorm(data=conv)
        return bn


def residual_factory(data, num_filter, dim_match):
    if dim_match == True:  # if dimension match
        identity_data = data
        conv1 = conv_factory(data=data, num_filter=num_filter, kernel=(3, 3), stride=(1, 1), pad=(1, 1),
                             act_type='relu', conv_type=0)

        conv2 = conv_factory(data=conv1, num_filter=num_filter, kernel=(3, 3), stride=(1, 1), pad=(1, 1), conv_type=1)
        new_data = identity_data + conv2
        act = mx.symbol.Activation(data=new_data, act_type='relu')
        return act
    else:
        conv1 = conv_factory(data=data, num_filter=num_filter, kernel=(3, 3), stride=(2, 2), pad=(1, 1),
                             act_type='relu', conv_type=0)
        conv2 = conv_factory(data=conv1, num_filter=num_filter, kernel=(3, 3), stride=(1, 1), pad=(1, 1), conv_type=1)

        # adopt project method in the paper when dimension increased
        project_data = conv_factory(data=data, num_filter=num_filter, kernel=(1, 1), stride=(2, 2), pad=(0, 0),
                                    conv_type=1)
        new_data = project_data + conv2
        act = mx.symbol.Activation(data=new_data, act_type='relu')
        return act


def residual_net(data, n):
    # fisrt 2n layers
    for i in range(n):
        data = residual_factory(data=data, num_filter=64, dim_match=True)

    # second 2n layers
    for i in range(n):
        if i == 0:
            data = residual_factory(data=data, num_filter=128, dim_match=False)
        else:
            data = residual_factory(data=data, num_filter=128, dim_match=True)

    # third 2n layers
    for i in range(n):
        if i == 0:
            data = residual_factory(data=data, num_filter=256, dim_match=False)
        else:
            data = residual_factory(data=data, num_filter=256, dim_match=True)

    return data


def get_symbol(num_classes=10):
    conv = conv_factory(data=mx.symbol.Variable(name='data'), num_filter=64, kernel=(3, 3), stride=(1, 1), pad=(1, 1),
                        act_type='relu', conv_type=0)
    n = 3  # set n = 3 means get a model with 3*6+2=20 layers, set n = 9 means 9*6+2=56 layers
    resnet = residual_net(conv, n)  #
    return resnet

net = get_symbol()

e = net.simple_bind(ctx=mx.gpu(0),
                    grad_req="null",
                    data=(1, 3, 1000, 1000))
import random
for i in range(1000):
    temp_shape = (1, 3, random.randint(600, 900), random.randint(600, 900))
    e_t = e.reshape(data=temp_shape)
    e_t.forward(is_train=False)
    output = e_t.outputs[0].copyto(mx.cpu()).asnumpy()
```

@piiswrong I don't know if I made it clear. For implementing RNN and many other cases, users need to explicitly create shared weight and bias symbols between different operators, we cannot follow the naming convention you mentioned.

@piiswrong: are you referring to using this interface (https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/include/mxnet/operator.h) explicitly? So you would need two separate functions: one for the forward chain of ops, and one for the backward chain?
